centration is small, meaning that these samples are very
As a proof of lighting application, the green-emit-
ting zeolite-3A: 1.3 wt% Eu phosphor is encapsulated
on a UV-emitting chip to fabricate green LED. The
EL emission spectrum at 3 V voltage is shown in
a. It can be found that the emission peaks of
the UV-emitting chip and the green-emitting phos-
phor are located at ~ 375 nm and ~ 523 nm, respect-
ively. And the inset is the photograph of working
green LED that emits bright green light at 3 V volt-
be (0.295, 0.537) for the resulting green LED, indicat-
In this work, we have obtained a bright green emission
phosphor with a quantum yield of about
36.6% and the emission peak located at 523 nm through a
green and eco-friendly high-thermal reaction method
without any reducing atmosphere. In addition, the sample
has a broad excitation band in the range of 310
which can be corresponded to the commercial UV-chip
ually incorporated in the zeolite host lattices as the calcin-
ation temperature increases. Our research shows that the
optimum sintering temperature is 1400 °C and the best
doping concentration of Eu ions is 1.3%. Making use of
lated on a UV-emitting chip, a good green LED with the
ordinates at (0.295, 0.537) and brightness of 231.6 cd/m
is obtained. And the green emission zeolite-3A: 1.3 wt%
Eu phosphors with increasing luminescent properties will
be promising applications for lighting and display.
Eu: Europium; FESEM: Field emission scanning electron microscope;
LED: Light-emitting diode; PL: Photoluminescence; PLE: Photoluminescence
excitation; RE: Rare-earth; TG: Thermogravimetric analysis; XPS: X-ray
GTF and HEW designed the experiments. HEW and GTF analyzed the data.
GTF, HEW, XLM, ZMH, XDG, YSW, JXZ, and LDZ discussed the results and
contributed to the writing of the manuscript. All authors read and approved
